docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: This guide provides all the necessary information to help you get started with contributing to our documentation, which is composed of Markdown documents in our GitHub repository and is automatically built using MkDocs whenever a pull request is merged.

docs.title: Getting started
docs.text:
First, you'll need to set up your environment for making contributions:

  1. Fork the repository: Go to our GitHub repository and fork it to your GitHub account.
  2. Clone the fork: Clone your forked repository to your local machine to make changes.
  3. Install MkDocs (Optional): If you wish to preview your changes locally, you'll need to install MkDocs. Follow the installation guide on their website.

docs.title: Adding/Editing content :
docs.text:
1. Create a new branch: Before making any changes, create a new branch in your forked repository.
  2. Add/Edit Markdown Files: Make your changes or add new content in the appropriate Markdown (.md) files, located in the docs/ directory.

docs.title: Previewing Your Changes
docs.text:
If you've installed MkDocs locally, you can preview your changes by running the following command in your project directory: 

mkdocs serve
This will start a local web server. Open your web browser and go to http://127.0.0.1:8000 to see your changes.

docs.title: Submitting Your Contributions
docs.text:
Once you are satisfied with your changes:

  1. Commit your changes: Add your changes to your fork and commit them with a clear commit message.
  2. Push to your fork: Push your changes to your GitHub fork.
  3. Create a pull request: Go to the original repository and create a new pull request. Target the main branch for your pull request and provide a clear description of your changes.

Your pull request will be reviewed and merged :)

docs.text: We're thrilled to have you join us. This guide is designed to help you get settled in, find the resources you need, and connect with our community.

docs.title: Accounts
docs.text:
You will primarily have two types of accounts:

  1. Lab-managed accounts: Managed by the IT team at your research lab.
  2. University-managed accounts: Managed by Sorbonne University.

docs.title: Webmail account
docs.text:
Login of the form jane.doe@dalembert.upmc.fr. Allows you to connect to the lab webmail. Ask the IT team to get one.

Note

You will also receive an email alias in the format jane.doe@sorbonne-universite.fr. This isn't a separate email account - it's simply an alias (forwarder) to your lab email. Any messages sent to this address will be automatically forwarded to your primary lab email address.

If you do not receive this alias automatically, contact Simona.

docs.title: Intranet account
docs.text: Login of the form jdoe. Useful to access some intern ressources of the lab (office booking).

docs.title: Sorbonne University accounts
docs.text:
You should automatically be assigned an account ID and password upon signing your contract with the university. Check that it works on the Annuaire UPMC webpage.

Each time you want to access a Sorbonne University service, you will need to use this account.

Note

If, like most PhD students at the lab, Sorbonne University is both your employer and your university, you will get two accounts : 1. A student account, the login being your student ID 2. An employee account, the login being a username

Most of the time, the second one is all you need. Every service is accessible via an employee account. The reciprocal is not true

docs.title: Before you arrive
docs.text:
Remember to fill out the inscription form at least two weeks before your arrival. This form helps automatically trigger:

  • Office allocation
  • Access key request
  • LDAP account creation (if you requested an "account on calculation room" – this is needed for lab intranet access).

Ask your supervisor (N+1) for details needed to complete the form.

docs.title: Crous (University restaurant)
docs.text:
Only available if you have a Sorbonne University or CNRS work contract. Once you have an Annuaire UPMC account:

  • Grab a copy of your work contract and your ID card / passport.
  • Go to the Crous building. Find the help desk (to your right as you enter).
  • (optional) Install the Izly app on your smartphone and link your account.

Info

Saint-Cyr Canteen: Ask Anne Marchal for a badge for the INRA canteen.

docs.title: Email account
docs.text:
You can access your emails by

  1. Using the webmail
  2. Using your preferred email client

To setup your email client, you will need to fill these informations.

IMAP server for incoming messages : 

imap server:    imap.dalembert.upmc.fr
encryption:     SSL/TLS
port:           993
login:          Your lab credentials (jane.doe@dalembert.upmc.fr without domain)

SMTPS server for outgoing messages : 

SMTPS server:   smtps.sorbonne-universite.fr
encryption:     SSL/TLS
port:           465
login:          Your Sorbonne University credentials

Important

Outgoing mail requires Sorbonne credentials - messages won't send if you use lab credentials

docs.title: Wired
docs.text:
Only lab computers can connect to the lab network. If you have a new lab computer:

  • Find your computer and/or internet hub mac address.
  • Send a mail to the IT department or go and see them: corridor 55/65, 5th floor, office 507. Ask if your device can be enabled on the lab network.

Warning

Only Linux or Mac OS systems are allowed for wired connections at Jussieu.

docs.title: Wireless
docs.text:
Connect to eduroam with your Sorbonne University credentials. See this page or this one for setup.

Info

Some services like Spotify don't work on this network. You can bypass that by using a VPN.

docs.title: Doctoral missions
docs.text: PhD students can apply for a doctoral mission (teaching, promotion of research results, expert assignments, scientific mediation). Find more on this website.

docs.title: Printers
docs.text: Follow instructions on the Lab Wiki - Imprimantes for setup.

docs.title: Room booking
docs.text: Connect to the lab room booking service with your d'Alembert intranet credentials.

docs.title: SSH
docs.text: Create a public/private SSH key pair on your personal computer. Email IT (info@dalembert.upmc.fr) with your public SSH key, requesting access to lab machines via vauban.dalembert.upmc.fr and chagall.dalembert.upmc.fr.

docs.title: Navigo (public transport)
docs.text: Sorbonne will reimburse part of your Navigo pass. See this page for details.

docs.title: Eco-mobility (bike, e-scooter, ...)
docs.text: To encourage the use of more sustainable transportation methods, staff members who choose alternative and eco-friendly modes of transport for their home-to-work commute may be eligible for an annual subsidy of up to €300. See this page for details.

docs.title: Upon Arrival
docs.text:
During the first few days, you must:

  1. Sign Your Contract: Your first official step with your employer.
  2. Sign your Installation Report (Procès Verbal d'Installation)
  3. Register at the Doctoral School (ED SMAER):
    • Most PhDs at d'Alembert are part of ED SMAER (École Doctorale Sciences Mécaniques, Acoustique, Électronique et Robotique de Paris).
    • Directors: Djimédo Kondo and Faiz Ben Amar.
    • Secretary: Charlotte Vallin (corridor 45-46, room 205).
  4. Register at Sorbonne Université:
    • After doctoral school registration, register at the university.
    • Fees: ~380€ (registration) + ~90€ (CVEC).
    • This provides your student card.

docs.title: Webservices
docs.text: A curated list of webservices.

docs.title: D'Alembert services
docs.text:
Managed by the IT team. Use your lab credentials to connect or create a new account when needed.

  • Nextcloud : cloud collaboration platform
  • Jitsi : video conferencing platform
  • Mattermost : team messaging platform
  • Gitea : Git service platform
  • GRR : office booking platform

docs.title: Sorbonne University services
docs.text:
Managed by Sorbonne University. You can check the status of those services here.

  • Nextcloud : cloud collaboration platform
  • AmongSU : Element (Discord-like) messaging platform
  • VPN : a VPN hosted by SU
  • Jitsi : video conferencing platform
  • BigBlueButton : video conferencing platform
  • Gitlab : Git service platform

docs.title: RENATER services
docs.text:
Services managed by other structures (CNRS), but accessible via your Sorbonne University credentials.

  • Rendez-vous : video conferencing platform
  • FileSender : large file transfer
  • Evento : events planner
  • PLMLatex : CNRS-hosted overleaf
  • Mattermost : team messaging platform
  • CodiMD : real-time collaboration Markdown editor
